long_desc.thetext: Created attachment 238387 Test file referred to in comment 0

I wonder if CaptureBinding18 should be a subtype of CaptureBinding at all as the is for wildcard capture. Perhaps it should be a direct subtype of TVB with a name like TransientTypeVariableBinding or InducedTypeVariableBinding or something like that ?

(In reply to Srikanth Sankaran from comment #3) > I wonder if CaptureBinding18 should be a subtype of CaptureBinding at all as > the > is for wildcard capture. Perhaps it should be a direct subtype of TVB with a > name > like TransientTypeVariableBinding or InducedTypeVariableBinding or > something like that ?
I was going back and forth a bit on this. Finally, it seemed that CaptureBinding is the closest relative among the types we already had.
In JLS7, capture conversion (5.1.10) says, e.g.,: "If Ti is a wildcard type argument (4.5.1) of the form ?, then Si is a fresh type variable whose upper bound is ..." Ergo, these are "type variables" that are invented during compilation.
The thing I named CaptureBinding18 corresponds to a concept used in JSR335 18.4: "Let Z1, ..., Zn be fresh type variables ... ... then define the lower bound of Zi as lub(L1, ..., Lk) ... ... define the upper bound of Zi as glb(U1, ..., Uk). ..."
So for these variables it is essential that they can have both upper and lower bounds, and (in contrast to *inference variables*) they survive type inference and will be used still for codegen.
Seeing your suggestion "TransientTypeVariableBinding" seems like you were thinking of "inference variables" (18.1.1), that only exist *during* inference?
I'll look into the reason for the NPE shortly.

I've released via http://git.eclipse.org/c/jdt/eclipse.jdt.core.git/commit/?h=BETA_JAVA8&id=d4fb0fb51b1c723a05d230645f038ab08aa3a386 :
- test from comment 0 with fix to make it pass in pure compilation mode (vs. code select)
- adjusted test from comment 2 (passes, too)
We still have bug 425183 for further improvements regarding CaptureBinding18. The example in this bug can indeed be exploited by, e.g., converting it into a code selection test.
